quiz.title: Resource Model and Structure
quiz.description: FHIR resource selection, element suitability, search parameters, extensions, and terminology

questions.stem: A hospital needs to store multiple identifier types for patients (SSN, Medical Record Number, Insurance ID). Which FHIR element should be used?
questions.explanation: Patient.identifier is an array designed to hold multiple business identifiers. Each identifier can have a type, system, and value to differentiate between SSN, MRN, etc.

questions.stem: When recording vital signs, laboratory results, and survey responses, which approach follows FHIR best practices?

choices.label: Use different resource types for each category
Use Observation resources with appropriate category codes
Create custom resources for each type

questions.explanation: Observation resources can represent various types of clinical data. Use the category element with standard codes (vital-signs, laboratory, survey) to distinguish between different types of observations.

questions.stem: To find all Observations for a specific patient from the last 6 months, which search parameters would you use?
questions.explanation: Use 'subject' to specify the patient and 'date' with 'ge' (greater than or equal) prefix for the time range. The subject parameter works for all resource types that reference patients.

questions.stem: A coded element in FHIR has a 'required' binding strength. What does this mean for implementation?

choices.label: The code is optional and can be omitted
Only codes from the specified value set are allowed
Codes can be extended with additional values
Text can be used instead of codes

questions.explanation: 'Required' binding means only codes from the specified value set can be used. This ensures interoperability but limits flexibility. Other binding strengths (extensible, preferred, example) offer more flexibility.

questions.stem: When should you use FHIR extensions instead of core resource elements?

choices.label: Always use extensions for custom data
When core elements don't meet your specific use case

questions.explanation: Use extensions only when core FHIR elements don't adequately represent your data. Always check if existing elements can be used first. Extensions should be defined in implementation guides for consistency.

questions.stem: Which approach correctly represents a reference from an Observation to its associated Patient?
questions.explanation: References in FHIR use the Reference data type with a 'reference' field containing the resource type and ID (e.g., 'Patient/123'). The subject field is the correct element for patient references in Observation.

questions.stem: A FHIR element has cardinality '1..*'. What does this mean for your implementation?

choices.label: At least one value must be provided

questions.explanation: Cardinality '1..*' means one or more values are required. '0..1' is optional single value, '1..1' is required single value, '0..*' is optional multiple values.

questions.stem: When should you use contained resources within a FHIR resource?

choices.label: When the contained resource has no independent existence

questions.explanation: Use contained resources only when the resource has no meaningful existence outside the containing resource. Most resources should be separate with references. Contained resources cannot be referenced by other resources.

questions.stem: What's the difference between Coding and CodeableConcept data types in FHIR?

choices.label: Coding is for multiple codes, CodeableConcept is for single codes
CodeableConcept can contain multiple Coding elements plus text

questions.explanation: CodeableConcept is a higher-level construct that can contain multiple Coding elements (allowing translations between code systems) plus a text description. Coding represents a single code from one system.

questions.stem: Your implementation uses a Patient profile that marks Patient.gender as required (cardinality 1..1). What must you ensure?

choices.label: All patients must have a gender value
Gender can be omitted for privacy
The profile requirement can be ignored

questions.explanation: Profile constraints are binding. If a profile requires gender (1..1), all Patient resources must include a gender value. However, FHIR R4 includes 'unknown' as a valid gender value if the actual gender is unknown.

questions.stem: In a FHIR profile, an element is marked with 'mustSupport=true'. What does this mean for implementers?

choices.label: The element must always be present
The system must be able to handle this element meaningfully

questions.explanation: mustSupport means the system must support the element if it's present - can store, retrieve, process, and/or display it meaningfully. It doesn't require the element to always be present.

choices.label: Split large resources into smaller ones
Define constraints on array elements based on distinguishing characteristics
Create multiple versions of a resource

questions.explanation: Slicing allows you to define specific constraints on different 'slices' of an array based on discriminator values. For example, slicing Patient.identifier by type to have specific rules for SSN vs MRN.
